solution_03_central_limit_theorem/03_central_limit_theorem/12_binom_less_v1

video

We determine the mean and standard deviation of the binomial distribution. \[\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (97)(0.57) ~=~ 55.29\] \[\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(97)(0.57)(0.43)} ~=~ 4.8759307 \]

We determine a \(z\)-score. (In the de Moivre-Laplace notes, I used \(\sum x\) to emphasize that a binomial variable is a sum of Bernoulli trials. Here, I will just use \(x\) as the boundary for number of successes, because this is the more common notation.) \[\begin{aligned} z &= \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{52.5-55.29}{4.8759307} \\\\ &= -0.5721985 \end{aligned}\]

Then, find the standard normal probability.

\[P(Z < -0.5721985) ~=~ 0.2835938 \]

Of course, you could have rounded \(z\), so the following will also get credit. \[P(Z < -0.58) ~=~ 0.281 \] \[P(Z < -0.57) ~=~ 0.2843 \]
